p.seg: The fool was devoid of wisdom
and so he just ate salt.
When he had eaten this, his mouth felt uncomfortable
and contrary to his intentions the salt became his misfortune.
The fool stands for those dissenters:
They hear that by controlling what they drink and eat they can obtain the Buddhist Way
and so they cut off nourishment.
Some survive for seven days,
others survive for fifteen days.
to no good purpose they make themselves miserable and hungry,
and they make no progress towards the Buddhist Way.
They are like that fool:
Because of the good taste of salt he went ahead and ate nothing else.
He caused his mouth to feel uncomfortable,
and this is also like the case of the dissenters.
When he had made these thoughts
he then got hold of a buffalo, mother and daughter,
and tied them up, each in a different place.
And then, one month later,
only at that time did he set up his party
and he received and placed his guests.
Only then did he pull along the buffalo
and he wanted to milk her.
But the milk of this buffalo had already dried up and there was none left.
At this time he was either stared at angrily or laughed at by the guests.
The fools are also like this:
they wish to cultivate the making of donations,
and then they say:
Let's wait until I have a lot of the stuff,
and only then will I make the donations at one go.
Before they have accumulated the stuff
it may be either taken away by district officials, or by floods or fires, or by thieves or robbers,
or indeed they may suddenly meet death,
and do not at the proper time make their donations.
That person (in the above story) is the same as these.
The fool replied as follows:
People like these are arrogant and throw their weight about.
They are stupid and have no wisdom.
They see that there is no hair on my head,
and they consider it to be a stone.
So they smash my head with a pear-tree stick, that's how it was."
The bystander said:
"You're silly as hell yourself!
How can you call these people names and consider them to be silly?
If you were not silly,
then would you have been beaten by them,
and would it have got to the point where your head was smashed,
without your finding a way of escaping?
The monks are also like this:
they are unable to practise asceticism, to be faithful to prohibitions and to listen to wisdom.
all they sort out is their external impressive behaviour
in order to attract beneficial sustenance.
Just like that fool
who suffers his head being beaten by others:
he does not know to get away
and even gets to the point of being severely injured.
And still he imagines others are silly.
These monks are just the same.
At this point she secretly told an old lady:
"After I am gone,
you should provide the dead body of a lady and place her in the house,
and you you must talk to my husband
and say that I have died."
The old women waited until a time when her master, the husband, was not at home
and she took a dead body
and put it in his home.
When the husband returned,
the old woman told him:
"Your wife has died."
The husband then went out to have a look
and indeed it turned out (to his mind) to be his own wife.
He grieved and lamented, and he was deeply upset.
On a large scale he assembled firewood and oil
and he burnt her, and took away her bones
and put them into a bag.
Day and night he kept the bones on his bosom.
The woman, after this, got fed up with her lover
and so she returned to her home.
She told her husband:
"I am your wife."
The husband replied to her and declared:
"My wife has died a long time ago
Who are you?
to baselessly claim you are my wife."
Right until she brought this up several times
but still her husband would not believe her.
He is like those dissenters
who, having heard deviant preachings
produce confused intellectual attachments in their minds,
and they wrongly consider these to be true
and to be permanently impossible to improve on.
Even if they do hear the true teaching
they will not believe in it or accept it.
A bystander spoke to him as follows:
You were suffering thirst and were running after water.
Now you have arrived at the place where the water is,
so why are you not drinking from it?
The fool replied as follows:
"If a lord can drink it up, (Zhou Shaoliang reads Ming Zang: 若 for 君）
then I ought to drink it.
But this water there is a lot of,
I could never drink it up.
Therefore I am not drinking.
At that time everybody who heard him saying this laughed out aloud.
It is the same with the dissenters who one-sidedly pick out their principles
and because they cannot completely manage all the prohibitions of the Buddha
they therefore do not accept them at all,
and so they bring it about that for their future they never achieve the proper Way,
and they drift on in the realm of life and death.
They are like that fool
who sees the water but does not drink from it，
and who is laughed at by his time/contemporaries.
They are also like this.
At the time when the fool heard these words
he thought to himself:
"If I cannot leave him
and must bury him (outside),
then I'll have to kill another son
to balance the two ends of carrying pole,
only that way will I be able to reach my destination."
At that point he then killed another of his children
took them on a carrying pole,
and, far away, buried them in the wooded open countryside.
At the time, when other people saw this,
they laughed intensely
and were amazed at it as unprecedented.
This is like the monks
who have secretly offended against one prohibition
and who then are all afraid to make amends
but who keep quiet about their transgression and hide it.
They say about themselves that they are pure,
but before they know it there will be wise men
who will say to them:
"Monks will keep to the Buddhist prohibitions
as if they were guarding bright pearls
which they will insure do not drop to the ground.
Why is it that having offended against what you have accepted (as prohibitions) you insist on not repenting?"
The one who had offended against the prohibitions said:
"If I really need to repent,
then I will first offend against the prohibitions again
and only after that I should leave this practice."
And so he broke the prohibitions
and engaged in many bad acts,
and only after that did he suddenly leave this practice.
It is like that fool:
When one son has died
he goes on to kill the other son.
These monks of our times are also like that.
A bystander said:
"You're a fool!
How come you call him your elder brother when you need property,
and when he has debts
you go on to say he is not your brother?"
The fool replied as follows:
"Because I want to get his property I acknowledge him as an elder brother,
but in fact he is not my elder brother.
If he had debt
then I would call him 'not my brother'."
When others heard this talk
they all laughed at it.
It is like those dissenters:
when they hear the good talk of the Buddha,
they steal it and use it,
and the consider it to be their own.
When it comes to the point where a third person tells them to to put these things into practice,
they refuse to put it into practice
and make the following speech:
"For concrete benefit
I choose what the Buddha said
to transform and guide all living creatures,
but since this does not correspond to reality
how could I cultivate it?" (cf. Schlegel: have you ever seen a signpost move in the direction it shows?)
It is like the case of the fool above:
in order to get the wealth,
he said: "He is my brother."
but when the man was in debt,
on the contrary, he said: "He is not my brother."
This case is also like that.
The King ordered him to put on the dress,
but in fact because it was not something that the Qiāng in the mountains have, (OR: did not belong the man)
he was unable to put it on.
What needed to be put on the hands, he wore on his legs,
what needed to be put on the waist he, on the contrary, wore on his head.
When the king saw the thief
he called together the ministers
to discuss this matter with them,
and he spoke to them as follows:
"If this really is the garment that from your grandfather's time has belonged to your family,
you should know how to wear it.
How come you wear it upside down,
wearing the top on the bottom.
This is because you you do not know how to wear the thing.
I know for sure that the garment you are wearing is certainly stolen,
and that is not your old property.“
This relies on the story to make a comparison/parable.
The king is like the Buddha,
the precious hidden treasure is like the dharma,
and the stupid barbarian is like the dissenters.
They secretly listen to the dharma of the Buddha
and the put it into their own dharma,
wrongly considering that they have it themselves.
But because they do not understand these things
in arranging the Buddhist dharmas
they turn things upside down
and not according to the the features of the dharma.
They are just like that mountain barbarian
who got hold of the king's royal garment
who is unaware of the proper arrangement of it on his body.
and who wears it upside down.
He is also like this.
The people asked him as follows:
"What kind of virtuous conduct did he have?
Please let us have the concrete facts."
The stupid man answered as follows:
"From his childhood my father cut out all lewd desires
and from the very start he was in no way defiled."
The people around said to him:
"Well, if he cut out all lewd desires,
how did he beget you?"
The man was laughed at in amazement by the people of his time.
He was like the ignorant sort in our own times.
They want to praise the virtues of a man
but they are unaware of the real facts about him.
And so they get to the point where they are maligned themselves.
Just like that fool,
who with the best intentions wanted to sing the praises of his father,
but his words amounted to attributing a mistake to him.
It is also like this.
"I have property and money,
no less than he.
Why did i not, in the past, build myself a house like that?
And he called up a carpenter
and asked him, speaking as follows:
"Can you build a neat house like that or can't you?"
The carpenter answered and said:
"But this building is my work!"
Then the man spoke to him as follows:
"You go ahead and build a house like that for me!"
At that point the carpenter laid out the terrain and piled up the clay in preparation for the house.
When the fool saw the carpenter piling up the clay foundations for making the house
he still had his doubts and uncertainties,
and unable to understand the situation
he asked the carpenter:
"What are you trying to do?"
The carpenter replied:
"I am building the three-storey house."
The fool went on to say:
"I don't want the rooms in the lower two storeys.
You should first build the upper rooms for me.
The carpenter answered as follows:
"There is no such thing.
How could it be that without building the lowest storey rooms one gets to build the second floor;
and without building the second floor,
how can one get to build the rooms on the third floor?
The fool insisted and said:
"I have no use now for the lower two storeys.
You must build the top floor for me!"
At the time, whenn other people heard about this
they generated in themselves blame and laughter,
and they made the following speech:
"How can one have anyone who does not build the first floor
and gets to the upper ones?"
This like the Buddha's four kinds of disciples.
They are unable to use proper spiritualediligence and to cultivate and respect the Three Treasures.
They are all lazy and devoid of energy,
but they desire to seek the fruits of the Way of Buddhism,
and they speak as follows:
"We do not now need the other three Fruits of Buddhist wisdom,
we shall only want to get that fruit of Aluohan-wisdom."
These will also get laughed at by the people of their times.
They are like that fool, all the same and no different.
The brahman said:
"Now this small child will die within seven days,
I am moved by its very early death
and that is the only reason I am moaning."
The people at the time told him:
"Human life is hard to predict
when one makes one's calculations one tends to get things wrong.
Suppose now that within these seven days by any chance the child is able to survive,
then why are you now weeping before the event?"
The brahman said:
"Sun and moon may eclipse and get darkened,
stars and constellations may fall out of the sky.
In what I have predicted I have never made a mistake."
For the sake of material benefit,
when the seventh day came,
he killed his own child
in order to prove the correctness of his own prediction.
At that time his contemporaries, after seven days, when they heard that his child had died,
all sighed and said:
"He is truly a wise man.
What he says does not turn out untrue."
In their minds they generated trust in the man
and they all came to show him their respect.
This is like the four kinds of disciples of the Buddha
who, because of material benefits obtained,
claimed that they had achieved the Buddhist Way,
but who actually had the dharmas of the fool in this story.
He killed this perfectly fine young person (his son),
in order to fraudulently show off his warm concern and virtuous talents.
In this way they bring about that in their future they suffer endless bitterness.
They are indeed like the brahman who, in order to prove the truth of his own words, killed his son and confused his contemporaries.
A bystander told him:
"If underneath you do not stop the fire
and keep fanning it,
then how are you going to cool this down?"
At that time all the people around laughed at him.
These are like the dissenters who fail to extinguish the blazing flames of their worries
but who on a small scale practise asceticism
and who rest on brambles,
but of whom the Five Fires roast the bodies,
but who hope for the Way of pure coolness and of peace.
To the end of their days they achieve none of their ends.
They are only blamed and laughed at by the wise of this world.
Their suffering bitterness is present in the current world
and their misfortunes flow into their future kalpas.
A bystander asked him as follows:
"Why are you beating him?"
The man replied as follows:
"When was I ever given to anger and rashness?
But this man claims that I always fly into rages and am rash in action.
That is why I beat him."
The bystander talked to him as follows:
"This very moment the evidence of your taste for anger and your rashness is manifest
why do you make a taboo of it?"
By talking about the faults, the man gave rise to resentment and accusations,
The other people around were profoundly amazed at his stupidity and confusion.
He is like the winoes of this world
who are steeped in alcohol,
and who commit licentious acts
for which they are criticised by others.
But they generate resentment in their hearts.
As best they can they cite evidence
and using this evidence they explain their own position.
They are like this fool
who cannot stand hearing about his own faults.
When he notices others talking about it
he had a desire to beat up the man who was talking.
When they had found a suitable person
leading each other along they set out
and reached an open field.
There was a temple for sacrifices to Heaven there,
and they needed a human sacrifice before they could pass on.
At that point the merchants thought about things together and said:
"We are all relatives in our group!
How can there be anyone to kill in this sacrifice?
There is only this sailing master who is fitting to be used as human sacrifice to Heaven."
And so they went ahead and killing the sailing master
so as to use him in the sacrifice.
When they had finished with their sacrifice,
they lost their way (having no longer their guide).
They did not know where to head for,
and they all died in dire straights.
All people of this world are like this.
They desire to enter the sea of the Buddhist dharma, and to pick up the treasures of Buddhism,
they must cultivate proper conduct of the good Buddhist dharma to make it their master.
But they ruin this good conduct
so that from the broad way of the cycle of life and death they will forever have no time at which they can leave.
They experience the three miserable ways of life(in hell, as beasts, as hungry ghosts),
and their suffering distress lasts forever.
They are like those merchants
who are about to go to sea,
but who kill their guide,
so that they lose their way to the fords (that lead the Buddhist truth).
And in the end they reach the stages of distress and death.

p.seg: Then, immediately we left for a distant place to obtain the drug.
After twelve years had passed,
he had got hold of the drug and returned with it.
He gave it to the daughter , told her to take the drug,
in order then to show her to the King.
When the King saw her he was delighted
and he then thought to himself:
"He is indeed an excellent physician:
by giving my daughter this medicine
he has been able to make her grow up so suddenly."
Thereupon he ordered his entourage to reward the physician with precious objects.
At this time everybody laughed at the king as being stupid
and for not understanding to calculate the time elapsed since the birth of his daughter,
and for the fact that when he saw that she had grown up
he imagined that this was because of the power of the drug.
The ordinary people of this world are also like this.
When they visit a person who is in the know/a Buddhist teacher
they start out by saying to him:
"I would like to seek the Truth,
I hope to be taught this by you
and that you will let me immediately get to the Truth.
Now the teacher who is in the know, because it is convenient will teach them to sit in meditation and to reflect on the conditions for the rise of the Twelve Causes.
They will then gradually accumulate all sorts of virtues
and they will ancieve Arhatship.
They will redouble their jumping about and be delighted
and they will speak thus:
"How terrific he is, our great master!
So quickly he can make me understand the most wonderful Dharma-truths.
Thereupon he squeezed his sugar cane
obtained the juice and used it to water the plant;
he was hoping for an ample sugary flavour,
but, on the contrary, he ruined the seeds;
and all the sugar cane he had was completely lost.
The common people of this world are also like this:
they desire to seek good fortune
and they rely on their own distinguished status;
they concentrate on their current situation and avail themselves of their positions of eminence,
they oppress the common people;
they violently aquire goods;
and thus they use these to produce good fortune.
Basically they expect good results (for their meritorious actions),
and they do not understand that in the future they will, on the contrary, reap disaster.
They are like those who squeeze the sugar cane,
and they will lose on all accounts.
For a debt of half a tael of cash he lost four taels of cash,
and at the same time he suffered exhaustion and the difficulties of travel.
What he was owed was very little,
and what he lost was very much.
In the end he was blamed and laughed by everyone.
The people of the world are also like this.
They crave material benefits that are unimportant
and they get to destroy the all-important matter of proper Buddhist conduct.
They give unconstrained liberties to their own persons,
and they take no heed of ritual and rectitude.
In the present visible world they suffer a bad reputation,
and in later existences they will get bitter retribution.
In this way, all the time, he went back and forth to sharpen the knife
and in the end he grew very tired.
He was afraid he could not keep going up so often,
and he hung up the camel upstairs
so as to move it to the grindstone and sharpen the knife.
He was profoundly laughed at by everyone.
He is like the fools
who destroy the Buddhist prohibitions
and who acquire lots of money and property
in order to cultivate their merit
in the hope to acquire immortality.
But their conduct is like hanging up the camel on the second floor in order to sharpen the knife.
The effort expended is very large,
the results obtained are very small.
Various people asked him:
"What are you trying to do?"
He replied as follows:
"I lost a water basin some time ago,
and I'm now trying to retrieve it."
They asked him and said:
"Where did you lose it?"
He replied and said:
"In the beginning when I went to sea I lost it.
They went on to ask:
"Since you lost it, how much time has passed?"
He said:
"I lost it a couple of months ago."
They asked him and said:
"If it is two months since you have lost it,
why look for it here?"
He replied and said:
"When I lost the basin
I made a mark in the water to make a record of this.
The water in which I made this mark is no different from the water here.
That is why I am looking for it in this place."
They went on to ask him:
"Even if the water is no different,
when some time ago you lost the thing
you were in that place,
and now you go looking in this place.
How would you ever find what you are looking for?"
Thereupon everyone, without exception, laughed out aloud.
They are just like the dissenters
who fail to cultivate the proper behaviour,
in the middle of merely apparent goodness they arbitrarily regard it as a cause for bitterness;
and by this means they seek to gain deliverance.
They are like the fool
who having lost his water basin in one place
goes on to look for it in another place.
Someone bore witness that this person had said nothing of the kind,
and the king, in his heart, then regretted what he had done.
He found a thousand taels of meat
and used it to build up the back.
During the night the victim was shouting (with pain)
and to a very great extent he suffered distress.
When the king heard this sound
he asked:
"Why are you so distressed?
I have taken a hundred taels from you,
and I have returned it to you tenfold.
Do you suppose that was not enough?
Why are you distressed?"
The bystander replied as follows:
"Your Grand Majesty
if you had had your son beheaded,
then even if you got a thousand heads in return,
it still is a stubborn fact that your son died.
Even if he gets ten times the amount of flesh
the stubborn fact remains that you suffer bitter pain."
The stupid people are also like this.
they have no fear of future existences,
and they crave present pleasures.
They inflict suffering on the living creatures
and they order about the Hundred Families.
They manage to get hold of much property
in the hope of thus being able to wipe out their crimes
and to obtain retribution in the form of happiness.
For example, that king
who was fleecing the back of the man
and took someone's flesh;
and then he used another person's flesh to replace that flesh,
hoping thereby to make sure the first man suffers no pain.
there is nothing commendable about this.
She asked the old lady:
"Sacrifice we must what?"
The old lady said:
"You must kill your son
take the blood and sacrifice it to Heaven.
Then you are sure to have many children."
Thereupon this woman, following that advice, wanted to kill her son.
Standing by was a wise man
who scoffed at her and scolded her to the face:
"You are utterly stupid,
and thus you have got to this point.
A son that has not yet been born, in the end he may be obtained, may he not be obtained?
But you are (already at this stage) killing your actual present son.
The fool is also like this:
for the sake of a not-yet materialised pleasure he throws himself into a firy pit
and he hurts himself in all sorts of ways,
all this in order to obtain immortality.
I have heard the following:
Once upon a time the Buddha lived in the city of the dwelling of the King,
In the Bamboo Park of Quèfēng he was together with all the great monks, bodhisattvas-mahāsattvas and 36 000 of the spirits and spiritual beings of the eight categories.
At that time within the saṅgha there were gathered five hundred heterodox brahmans.
They got up from their seats
and politely addressed the Buddha as follows:
"We have heard that the way of the Buddha is vast and profound
and such that nobody can reach it.
That is why we come here to ask about it.
We just hope that you will expound this way."
The Buddha said: "Very good!"
They asked: "Does the world count as existing or as non-existing?"
The Buddha replied as follows:
"It both exists and does not exist."
The brahmans said:
"Supposing now that it exists, then how can one say that it does not exist?
And supposing that it does not exist, how can one say that it does exist?"
The Buddha replied as follows:
"When something lives one says: 'it exists'.
and when something is dead one says: 'it does not exist'.
That is why one says:
'It may exist or it may not exist.'"
They asked as follows:
"What does man originate from."
The Buddha replied as follows:
"Man originates from grain."
They asked as follows:
"What do the five kinds of grain originate from?"
The Buddha replied as follows:
"The five kinds of grain arise from the Four Elements, from Fire and Air."
The brahmans asked as follows:
"What do the elements, Fire and Air originate from?"
The Buddha replied as follows:
"The elements Fire and Air arise from Emptiness."
The brahmans asked as follows:
What does Emptiness originate from?"
The Buddha replied as follows:
"It arises from where there is nothing."
The brahmans asked as follows:
"Where does 'where there is nothing' originate from?
The Buddha replied as follows:
"It originates from what is naturally so."
The brahmans asked as follows:
"Where does what is naturally so originate from?"
The Buddha answered as follows:
"It originates from Nirvāna."
The brahmans asked as follows:
"What does Nirvana originate from?"
The Buddha spoke as follows:
"As you now ask about matters,
why do you go so deep into it?
Nirvāna is a dharma that goes beyond life and death."
The brahmans asked as follows:
"Have you, the Buddha, reached Nirvāna or not yet?"
The Buddha replied as follows:
"I have not yet reached Nirvāna."
"But if you have not yet reached Nirvāna,
how can you know that Nirvāna is eternal bliss?"
The Buddha said:
"Now I will ask you:
'The various creatures of this world, do they live in bitterness or in delight?"
The brahmans replied as follows:
"The various creatures suffer intense bitterness."
The Buddha said:
"Why do you call this bitterness?"
The brahmans answered as follows:
"We see that when the various creatures die they suffer bitter pain and find it hard to bear,
thus we know that dying is bitter."
The Buddha said:
"You are not dead at this point,
but still you know that dying is bitter.
I have seen that the various Buddhas of the ten regions are neither born nor die,
therefore I know that Nirvāna is eternal bliss.
The five hundred brahmans were delighted and relieved,
and they sought to receive the Five Prohibitions.
They grasped the fruits of srotāpanna (first step towards enlightenment),
and they sat down again, as before.
The Buddha said:
"You people listen carefullly to me.
Now I will at length expound for you the various parables."
For many days he was unable to sell.
So in his mind he generated dissatisfaction
and he considered this troublesome.
He noticed that others, when selling charcoal, were able to sell it quickly
and he generated a thought as follows:
"It will be best to burn it up and make charcoal of it,
then it will be possible to sell it quickly."
Then he burnt it to produce charcoal,
went to the market and offered it for sale.
He did not even get the price of half a cartload of charcoal.
The fools of this world are also like this:
With innumerable expedient means they practise their earnest spiritual endevour and spiritual cultivations,
seeking the fruits of Buddhahood.
But because these are so hard to get
they then go on to develop a tendency to withdraw:
"It is best to make a determined decision to seek the rewards of monkhood and to quickly break of the cycle of life and death, and to become an arhat.
The fools of this world are also like this.
They do have the attitude of believers,
they enter into the dharmas of the Buddha,
and they cultivate the good dharmas of the Buddha as well as the meritorious virtues,
but because they do so for material benefit
they ruin the pure prohibitions and the meritorious virtues.
They are laughed at by the world,
and they are also like this fool.
The ordinary people of this world are also like this:
Because the Pusa practises his spiritual (austere) cultivation for ages on end
and since this was hard and bitter to practise,
they thought it no fun,
and they produced the thought:
"It is best to become an arhat
and quickly cut off the succession of lives and deaths.
This is very easy to achieve."
But when afterwards they desire to seek the fruits>ultimate state of Buddhahood
then they will never be able to get to it.
Now as for those scorched seeds
they will never have a basis for growing.
The fools of this world are also like this.
The people of this mundane world are also like this.
They enter into the dharmas of the Buddha,
they become monks and seek the way of the Buddha.
But after they have become monks
they still yearn for their wives and their kith and kin, for the affairs of this world and the pleasures of the Five Desires.
Because of this they lose the fire constituted by their meritorious virtue, and the cold water constituted by the keeping of the Buddhist prohibitions.
The people who are preoccupied by desires are also like this.
This man then went to the king's place,
and when the king was blinking, then in imitation of the king he blinked.
The king asked him as follows:
"Is there something wrong with you?
Or have you caught a cold?
Why are you blinking?"
The man replied to the king:
"There is nothing wrong with my eyes
and also I have not caught a cold.
I desire to gain Your Majesty's favour
and so when I see Your Majesty blink
accordingly, I imitate Your Majesty."
When the king heard these words
he then became very angry.
He thereupon ordered someone to inflict all sorts of harm on our man,
removed him from his presence and ordered him to leave the country.
The vulgar people of this world are also like this:
Regarding the king of Buddha-dharma they wished to cultivate his friendship,
and they sought his good dharmas:teachings
in order to make themselves grow spiritually.
When they had won his friendship
they failed to understand that the Tathāgata the king of dharma, for the sake of the living creatures,
he, as varying expedient means, manifested his shortcomings.
Someone heard his teaching
and saw that some formulations were not correct,
and he generated negative criticism.
They are imitating what was not right
and because of this they lose what is excellent in the dharma of the Buddha.
They fall into the three bad states.
That fool is also just like this.
The son whipped his back for him
and he applied horse's shit to the wounds
thinking that he was supremely cleaver.
The people of this world are also like this:
When they hear other people's pronouncements
they cultivate the view that the things of this world are impure
and then they get to remove the Five Obscurations and the injuries to the body (or fig:person??no!)
Then they make this speech:
"I wish to meditate on female beauty and on the Five Desires."
They do not yet realise that these are unclean things
but on the contrary they get all confused by female beauty.
They float along in the cycle of life and death,
and they fall into Hell.
The stupid people of this world are also like this.
Then he went along and cut of that other's woman's nose
took it along and returned home.
Urgently he called his wife.
"You come out quickly:
I'll give you a beautiful nose!"
When the wife came out
he cut off her nose
having looked for it, he placed the other woman's nose in his wife' face.
But since it did not stick together with the face.
she did lose her nose.
For no good reason he inflicted great pain on his wife.
The fools of this world are also like this
They hear that other senior monks and brahmans(two syllables!) have some great fame and virtue,
they are respected by the people of this world
and derive great material profit from them.
Then they produce a thought as follows:
"But I am no different from these!"
Without base he falsely applied (positive) terms to himself
and arbitrarily said that he had virtue.
On the one hand he lost his sustenance
and on the other he did damage to his demeanour.
It is like the cutting off of someone else's nose
and damaging oneself for no good reason.
The poor man was delighted
and followed his proposals respectfully.
This man then lit a fire in front of him
and told the poor man:
"Now you can take off your coarse dolichos garment."
and put it into the fire.
From this fact of putting it into the fire, this will cause you to get the supreme garment.
The poor man then took off his garment and put it into the fire.
After he had burnt it up
he looked in the place were it was burnt for this distinguished garment,
but he could not find any at all.
The people of this world are also like this.
They cultivate the good dharmas starting from their past persons
and they have obtained this human embodiment,
and they should have taken good care of it to promote virtue and cultivate positive karma,
but they get cheated by the dissenters and by the wicked witches, [who say]:
"You should now believe in our words
and cultivate the ascetic practices:
you must throw yourself from the high cliffs, and you must cast youself into the fire
and once you have rejected this embodiment
you will be reborn in the Heavenly Realm
and you will receive joy forever more!"
They follow this talk,
and they throw away their physical life.
After they have died in this physical world
they fall into hell
and they get their full share of suffering.
Once they have lost their human embodiment
they are empty and they have gained nothing.
Like this poor man
who is also like this.
At the time there was someone
who was an expert at cheating.
In order to create favourable convenient conditions
and went along to become freinds with him,
and he spoke to him as follows:
"We have now established a very intimate relationship
so that we have become one body,
and henceforth there is nothing that divides us.
I am aware in yonder family there is a beautiful woman
She should be pursued by you,
and she is suitable to become your wife.
The goat shepherd,
when he heard this, was delighted,
so on a large scale he gave him goats and possessions.
The man went on to say:
And your wife has now already given birth to one son."
Before the shepherd had even laid his eyes on the woman
when he heard that she had already delivered a child
he was delighted in his mind
and he doubled up this gifts of those kinds of things.
That men later went on to speak to him as follows:
"Your son, having been born, has now already died."
When the shepherd heard these words from the man
he started weeping and sobbing uncontrollably.
The people of this world are also like this.
Although they cultivate broad knowledge,
being concerned with their material profit and with keeping secret the proper dharma
they are unwilling to teach others and to preach for them.
They become cheated and mislead by this defiled person
and misguidedly hope for worldly delightes.
As in respect of their own wife and offspring he was cheated by that man
and he lost the good dharma.
Later they lose their physical life and their possessions
so they weep away loudly in their distress.
They generate their own worries and suffering
and they are like that goat-herd, who is also like this.
When the disciples saw this
they asked him as follows:
"Why are you sighing, and why are you so upset?"
The man replied as follows:
"As a convenient means I have laboured for years and then I have managed to make the vessel.
I went to the market and wanted to offer it for sale.
But this tottering ass, in one silly moment, shattered all my vessels.
That is why I am upset."
At that time, when the disciple had heard this
he was delighted and thought as follows:
"This donkey is a precious thing.
What has been produced over a long period he is able to ruin in a moment.
I must buy this donkey."
The potter was delighted
and sold it to the disciple.
Riding along he returned home.
The master asked him as follows:
"Why didn't you get the potter to come?
What am I going to use this donkey for?"
The disciple replied as follows:
"This donkey is superior to the master potter.
The vessels which the master potter can produce in a long time, the donkey can ruin in a moment."
Thereupon the master spoke to him as follows:
"You are stupid indeed, and you have no wisdom.
This donkey is now capable of destroying things,
but even in one hundred years he is incapable to complete a single one."
The people of this world are also like this.
Even if for thousands or hundreds of years they have received material benefits offered to them
they will not offer the slightest rewards.
Forever they go on harming their benefactors
and to the very end they do not benefit them in return.
The man who turned his back on generosity is also like that.
It is like these dissenters
who steal the dharma of the Buddha
and who put it in among their own dharma
claiming that it is their own
and that it is not the dharma of the Buddha.
But for this very reason
he is burning up (his own) heretical classics
and they do not gain currency in the world.
It is like this case of stealing the gold:
all the facts will come out.
It is also like this.
Then he cut down the tree
hoping to get the fruits.
On the one hand he did not get anything
and on the other only wore himself out.
Later he wanted to raise the tree again
but the tree had already withered to death
and had no life in it at all.
The people of this world are also like this.
The Tathāgatha Buddha, king of the Truth, has the "tree" of keeping to the precepts which is able to bring forth the victorious "fruits".
The heart generates the delight of hope
and wishes to obtain the "fruits" to eat.
Then one ought to observe the prohibitions
and to cultivate the meritorious virtues.
But they do not understand expedient means
and on the contrary they break the prohibitions.
It is like that man cutting down the tree
and at the same time desiring to return to life.
Those who break the prohibitions are also like this.
So he went to speak to the king
and the king obliged and changed the village
and he brought it to a distance of three yoúxūn.
When the villagers heard about this
they were overjoyed.
Someone told them as follows:
"This definitely is the original five yoúxūn (distance),
and there is no difference."
Although they heard these words,
because they believed the king's words
to the very end they refused to let go of their belief.
When the Hinayāna people learn their theories they are delighted
and they imagine these is easy to practice.
They cultivate goodness and promote in themselves virtue
and thus seek to get beyond the cycle of life/rebirth and death.
Then later they hear others say:
"There is no such thing as the three vehicles
so the point is the one Way."
Because they imagine these theories to be the words of the Buddha
they will never let go of these.
They are like those villagers,
they are also like this.
When the poor man saw this
he was greatly joyed in his mind
and he took off the lid.
Then he saw the man in the mirror
and he generated panic in him.
He crossed his arms and told this man:
"I thought this was an empty box
with nothing at all inside.
It never occurred to me that you were inside.
Please don't get angry at me!
Ordinary people are also like this.
They are troubled by endless worries
and they are tied down by the cycle of life and death and by the Lord of Hell, the Divine Creditor.
They wish to escape from the cycle of life and dewath
to enter into the dharmas of the Buddha,
to cultivate the good dharmas of the Buddha
and to create carmic merit.
It is like the case of running into the box with treasures in it:
by looking into the mirror themelves they are thrown into confusion.
They wrongly imagine that there is an "I",
and then they get fixed in their ways
and they imagine that this is the real truth.
At this stage they fall into an abyss
they lose their meritorious karma, the gifts of the dharma of meditation and the benefits of being without defilements.
The fruits of the Way of the Three Vehicles they all lose.
They are like that stupid man
who discarded the box of treasures.
Those who remain attached to the view that there is a Self are also like this.
There was a stupid minister
who then went up to the immortal's place;
he poked out both the eyes of that immmortal's eyes
and taking these along he addressed the king politely:
"Since I have poked out his eyes
he is not going to get to leave,
and he will permanently reside in this state!"
The king spoke to the minister as follows:
"The reason why we are so eager to have the immortal to stay
is that he is able to see all hidden stores in the earth.
Now you have ruined his eyes!
What can we go on to use him for?"
The people of this world are also like this.
They see a monk practising asceticism in the mountain forests, the wild open landscape, among the graves and under the trees.
He cultivates the stopping of the Four (wrong) Intentions and the (right) view concerning impurities.
And so they force him to come
and they make all sorts of polite offerings to him in their home.
They destroy his good ways of Buddhism
and they bring it about that the Buddhist Way is in the end not realised.
They lose the Eye of Buddhist Way
and they also lose their own benefits
so that they go empty-handed and get nothing.
They are like that stupid minister
who for no good reason destroyed someone else's eye.
The ordinary fools are also like this.
They receive the sufficient prohibitions of the Tathāgatha Buddha,
and when they have offended one prohibition they do not generate shame and pure remorse
but they a thought as follows:
"I have already broken one prohibition
and since the prohibitions are no longer totally respected
what use is it to hold on to them (at all)?"
And when they break all prohibitions
until one is left in place,
then they are like that fool
who killed all his many buffaloes
so that none was left.
Then he said angrily:
"I have already finished drinking
and I have told you not to come any more.
Why are you insisting on coming?"
Someone saw this and said:
"You are very stupid indeed
and you have no wisdom.
Why don't you just go your way
and tell the water: 'Do not come!'?"
Then the observer pulled the fool back
and pulled him to another place.
The people of the world are also like this:
for the sake of their physical desires regarding the cycle of rebirth and death
they drink the salty water of the Five Desires.
Since they are overfed by their Five Desires,
they are like that man who has drunk to his satisfaction
and they then make the following speech:
"You world of shapes and sounds, of flavours and tastes, do not come to me again so as to make me see you."
These Five Desires take over one from another, never interrupting themselves.
And when they see them,
they get angry:
"I told you to quickly disintegrate
and not to get born again!
Why do you insist on coming,
and on making me see you?"
At the time there was a clever man who said to him:
"If you want to get to get away from this
you must control your Six Feelings,
and you must shut off your subjective thoughts.
When your unfounded imaginings no longer arise
then you will get liberation.
Why should there be a need not to see/be exposed to them
and why do you wish to cause these not to arise again?
It is like that fool drinking water, and no different from them.
The fool then produced a thought which went as follows:
"If I only use the chaff of rice,
that is not as good as mixing rice and make the plaster in that way.
Then the wall can become white and clean
and the mud can be evened out nicely."
Then he used the chaff of rice and the mud
and with these he daubed his wall,
hoping that way to get to become even and straight.
But in fact it became even more uneven.
The wall was showing cracks everywhere.
At that point to discard the chaff of rice
will do him no good at all.
He would need to practice Buddhist generosity
in order to be able to get meritorious karma.
The ordinary people are also like this.
Having heard the sage preach the Buddhist truth
they cultivate the features of goodness
so that having rejected this person of their (very Buddhist expression)
they can get to become immortals and to achieve liberation.
And so they have themselves killed
hoping to get to become immortals and to achieve liberation.
All in vain, and to no purpose they allow themsleves to lose their lives,
and for nothing they gain nothing.
They are like this stupid person.
Now that doctor happened to be bald himself
and he took off his hat to show how bald he was,
and he spoke to his patient as follows:
"I have the same problem!
And I find it really hard to bear.
Supposing when I apply my cure
I can manage to get this disease cured
then I should first have cured myself and
got rid of my own problem!"
The people of this world are also like this.
because their lives are invaded and molested by birth, ageing, disease and death
they desire the feature of immortality.
They hear that among monks and brahmans there are the world's most competent physicians
and they go to their places
and they speak to them as follows:
"I just wish you could remove for me this problem of impermanence and of the cycle of life and death
and that I can find myself forever in peace and joy,
that I can survive forever without changing this state."
Then the brahmans reported as follows:
"We too suffer from impermanence, birth, old age, illness and death,
and all the features of permanence that we seek we do not in the end get.
Now if we can get you to succeed in getting them,
then we should also first get them outselves
and cause you to get them too."
They are like that man struck by baldness:
to no purpose he wears himself out
and he cannot get to cure himself.
The two devils answered as follows:
"This our box can produce all garments, nourishments, mattresses, bedding, and necessities of life, they all come out from it;
as for him who holds this staff， his worst enemies will rally to him and none will dare to quarrel with him;
as for him who wears these shoes, they are capable of causing a man to fly, and to ensure that in his movements he has no obstacles."
When this man heard that
he spoke to the devils as follows:
"You move off a little.
I shall divide these equally among you."
When the devils heard this speech
they immediately moved a good way off.
The man then took the box with both his handfs, picked up the staff, putt on the shoes and flew off.
The two devils were astonbished,
and in the end they got nothing.
The man then spoke to the devils as follows:
"What you people quarrel about I have already taken away.
And now I have ensured that you no longer will quarrel in the future."
The devils stand metaphorically for the various devils as well as the dissenters.
Generosity is like the box.
The Five Ways of men and devas, and utensils of daily use, all these come from it.
Meditation is like the staff:
it can annihilate the devils' resentment and that villain, the worries.
Conforming to the prohibitions is like those shoes:
one is bound to rise as men and devas.
The devils and dissenters who quarrel over the box stand metaphorically for seeking with all one's might karmic recompense while living among defilements:
this is in vain and there is nothing one achieves.
If one is capable of cultivating good comportment as well as generosity, and to keep the prohibitions and to meditate properly,
then one will reap the fruits of the Way of the Buddha.

div.head:
（四二）估客駝死喻
譬如估客 For example there was a trader

p.seg: The trader refused to walk away.
He sat down two followers of his
and spoke to them as follows:
"You diligently look after this camel hide
and make sure that it does not get wet and rotten!"
After this, it rained
and these two (disciple) men were quite stupid:
they put all the fine woolen mats on top of the hide
and the woolen mats all got thoroughly rotten.
The price of the hides and of the woolen mats are evidently quite different
but because of the their stupidity they covered the hide with the skin.
The people of this world are also like this.
The observance of the prohibition of killing stands metaphorically for the white woolen mats.
The camel hide is metaphorical for worldly possessions.
The rain moistening and ruining the mats stands metaphorically for being unrestrained and ruining the good (Buddhist) comportment.
The prohibition not to kill is the very trunk of the Buddhist dharma and the highest wonderful karmic deed,
but they cannot cultivate these things.
The only thing they do is to use worldly possesions to build temples
and to care well for the monks.
They discard the root and they opt for what is marginal:
they do not seek what is basic.
They float along in the Five Ways
and they can never extract themselves from these.
Therefore those who practise the Buddhist Way must concentrate their minds and conform to the prohibition not to kill
The people of this world are also like this.
The rubbing a large stone illustrates academic study.
The diligent effort put in to make a small buffalo illustrates fame.
Those who engage in study investigate and reflect on subtle things, acquire broad understanding and wide knowledge.
They ought to put this into practice and in the long perspective seek excellent results.
As soon as one starts seeking fame,
they to be arrogant and vain
and that will add to their based-on-mistakes>self-inflicted disasters
The people of this world are also like this:
From the outset they constantly were without true pleasure.
But stupidity and perversion
waywardly produced throughts regarding pleasure.
They are like that fool.
At the point of half a cake he produced the thought of satiation.
The people of this world understand nothing
and they take wealth and status for true pleasure.
As for wealth and honour, one has a hard time when one seeks these
and after one has got hold of them, holding onto them
one also has a hard time.
Then afterwards when one has lost them again
the worried thoughts are again bitter.
During day and night they never have true pleasures.
It is like garments and food,
they will cover your body (and feed you) and therefore be called pleasurable.
Within the world of bitter distress they waywardly produce the thought of pleasures.
The various Buddhas have spoken as follows:
「In the Three Realms there is no peace,
and everything is great bitterness.
When the vulgar person is perverted and confused,
he will waywardly give rise to thoughts about (vulgar) pleasures.」

div.head:
（四五）奴守門喻
PARABLE 45 The Slave Guarding the Gate

p.seg: After the slave had gone
as for the property in the house, thieves took it all away.
When the landlord came home from his trip,
he asked his slave as follows:
"And what about the place where the goods are?"
The slave then answered as followed:
"You, my lord, have given orders before concerning the gate, the donkey, and the rope.
Apart from this I know of nothing more."
The host went on to say:
"The fact that I have left yhou to guard the gate was exactly for the sake of my property.
Since the property is all gone,
what use do I have for the gate?」
The fools within this world of life and death, because they love their slaves, are also like this:
The teachings and prohibitions of the Tathāgatha are as follows:
keep constant guard over the Six Root Gates of Experience
and not to defile yourself with the Six Defilements:
one should guard the donkey of unenlightenment,
and one should look after the rope constituted by love.
And the monks will not uphold the teaching of the Buddha
but they crave material benefits (instead).
Fraudulently, they make a show of purity and they sit in meditation.
The thoughts in their minds race along all over the place
and through craving they are attached to the Five Desires;
they are thoroughly confused by the colours and the flavours,
and lack of enlightenment obfuscates their minds.
The rope of craving ties them up.
Correct Buddhist thinking, enlightened ideas, Buddhist decency, as well as worldly wealth are all lost for them.
He went on to ask:
"Next to the pond, isn't there a tree?"
They politely replied: "There is no tree."
He went on to ask:
"When they stole the ox, were you to the east of your village or not?
They replied: "There is no such thing as the east."
He went on to ask:
"When you stole the ox, was that not at mid-day?"
They politely replied: "There is no such thing as the middle."
He went on to ask:
"Even if (as you say) there is no village and no tree,
how can it be that in the world there is no east and not time of day?
I can see that you talk irresponsibly, and that you are not at all to be trusted.
Now: did you (or did you not) steal the ox and eat it?"
They politely replied:
"We have indeed eaten it."
Those who break the prohibitions are also like this.
They cover up their crimes
and they are not prepared to disclose them.
After their death they enter into hell.
All the good spirits of Heaven see things with their Heavenly Eye
and one cannot hide from them.
It is like these people eating the yak.
they are unable to
The husband was from before always good at imitating the cries of mandarin ducks
and he entered the king's pond,
where he made the sounds of mandarin ducks
and stole some utpala flowers.
At that time the the keeper of the pond addressed to him this question:
"Who is in in the pond?"
and this pauper came to answer as follows:
"I am a mandarin duck!"
The guard caught the pauper,
and lead him to the king's place.
But on the way, he started again with his imitation noises
and produced the cries of the mandarin duck.
The guard of the pond said:
"You did not do that before,
why do you go on to do it now?"
The fools of this world are also like this:
to the end of their days they do harm
and they create all sorts of bad karma;
they do not cultivate the practice of the mind,
so that they cause themselves to be attuned to the good.
Only when their lives come to an end
do they say: "Now I want to practice goodness!"
But the soldiers of hell allready lead them along to hand them over to the king of Hell.
Although they desire to practice goodness
they still definitely get nowhhere with it.
They are like that fool:
Only when he is about to reach the king's place
does he produce the sound of the mandarin duck.
From afar he saw that the storm was blowing against the large tree, and that the branches were being moved up and down,
and he thought: "It is calling me!"
And he immediately returned to the place under the tree.
Stupid disciples are also like this:
Having managed to become monks
they have managed to get close to a master,
but because of some slight verbal attack they then run away.
But again at a later time they meet evil friends
and they have unending troubles.
Only then they return to the master's place.
Like this they go back and forth and this must count as stupid confusion.
At that time, on the river bank, there was an immortal
and the two children went on quarelling incessantly.
They went to visit that immortal's place
in order to decide their controversial issue.
But this immortal immediately went on to pick up a grain of rice and "barbarian" sesame seed.
He chewed these in his mouth
spat them out into his palm
and told the children:
"What is in my palm is like a peacock turd.
And this immortal did not answer other questions,
everyone understood what was going on (he was not addressing the issue).
People in this world are also like this.
When they preach the Buddhist truths they play around with discussions of them
and do not address the straight principles.
Like that immortal, who did not answer what he was asked.
He was being laughed at by everyone.
People's frivolous empty explanations are also like this.
The Five Aggregates are also like this:
Troubles and karma elements combine to make our incarnations,
and these Five Aggregates will forever flay living creates with infinite worries of birth, old age, illness and death
The karmic rewards in this world are also like this.
Even if in this world among men or up in Heaven they receive some insignificant delights,
these still have no real substance.
They have no constancy, they will be ruined, and cannot not stay with you forever.
just like this music for nothing.
When the first disciple got back
he got angry at the second man acting like this.
He caught hold of the leg which the second disciple was massaging and immediately broke it.
The followers of the Buddhist dharma arealso like this.
The Mahayāna scholars criticise the Hīnayāna,
and the Hīnayāna in turn criticise the Mahayāna.
And thus they cause the Dharma Scriptures of the Great Buddha not even to exist in the three realms of miserable earthly life: hell, beasts, hungry ghosts
The disciples of Buddhist masters are also like this.
They claim their masters are old
and that they keep staying at the head.
We young people ought to become the leaders.
Young men like this do not understand the Buddhist prohibitions
and they will often break some of these.
And thus they pull each other so as to enter into hell.
The king said:
"If it is this matter that is in accordance with your ideas,
then I shall do as you desire."
A fool like this will be laughed at by the people of this world.
Even the administration of half the kingdom, or the position of a senior minister, of a senior leader, all these were his to obtain,
but he sought only a menial job.
The fools are also like this.
The various Buddhist in boundless kalpas egaged in difficult and ascetic practices so as to become Buddhas.
If they meet a Buddha and they run into transmitted Buddhist truths, even their human incarnation is hard to obtain.
It is as if a blind water turtle runs into a (suitable) hole in a piece of floating wood.
Both these are hard-to-get coincidences,
but on this occasion they have run into them.
And yet their ideas and plans were deficient.
The maintaining of petty prohibitions they then consider sufficient
and they do not seek the excellent wonderful Buddhist truth of Nirvana.
They do not have the spirit to seek spirital advancement.
For themselves they engage in evil deeds,
and this they regard as sufficient.
At that time the two men did help him to push his cart,
and they got it to a level place.
Then they told the man pushing the cart:
"Give me the thing (you promised)."
The man with his sesame cart replied: "Ithere is no thing."
They went on to say:
"Well then, give us what there is not."
One of the two people smiled and said:
"That man not being willing to give us anything, how should that be something to feel sad about?"
The other man replied:
"If he gives us what there is not,
then there must be what there is not."
The first man said:
"As for what there is not, the two characters are combined
and these make up a pseudo-name (which does not refer to anything).
The vulgar man in the street, when he runs into the concept of "what there is not"
then this gives rise to the place/item where there is nothing.
What the second person meant was:
"'What there is not' is none other than what has no features, no desires, and no function (i.e. there is no such thing as the "what there is not")."
Then, the senior person was just about to cough and spit.
At that time this fool then raised his foot and stepped on the senior person's mouth.
He ruined the lips and broke his teeth.
The senior person told the fool:
"Why are you kicking me in my mouth?"
The fool replied:
"If your spittle emerges from the mouth and falls on the ground
then all these flatterers in your entourage have already got to step on it so as to remove it.
Even if I want to tread on it, every time I fail.
For this reason, when the spittle comes out of your mouth I raise my foot and tread on it before it is too late,
and I hope in this way to gain your favour.
Every thing needs its proper time.
When the proper moment has not yet arrived
and one insists to make one's effort,
then, on the contrary, one will harvest troubles.
For this reason
people in this world must understand opportuneness of moments.
At that time there was a stupid old man who said:
"When I tell you to divide the things,
I want you to divide them evenly.
Now as for all things, you have ruin them so as to make two parts."
How did he ruin them?
Well, what this refers to is that as for garments he cut them up to make two parts
as for ???vessels he ruined them to make two parts,
as for ??? he also ruined them to make two parts,
and as for coins he also ruined them to make two parts.
In this way each and every piece of property he has in all cases ruined.
By dividing the things in this manner, he has become the laughing stock of others.
It is like the dissenters
who one-sidedly cultivate a separate theory.
There are four kinds of theories.
There are the theories that provide a definite answer.
For example humans all have the quality of universal mortality.
This is a case where one may answer an issue with definite certainty.
Someone who is dying must be alive.
This must be answered separately.
If his appetitive feelings are exhausted there is no life,
if he still has appetitive feelings he has life.
This is called the kind of proposition to which one must give separate answers.
If there is someone who asks whether man is the most excellent creature,
then one should ask back and say:
"Are you asking about the Way the Three Evils
or are you asking about the Heavens.
If you are asking about the Way of the Three Evils,
then man will indeed count as the most excellent.
But if you are asking about the Heavens
then man must count as not coming up to them.
These procedures are called "answer a problem by asking questions back.
If they ask you one of the Fourteen Tricky Questions
if they ask whether thtere is a limit or nor limit, if there is an end or no end to the world and to the living creatures,
cases like this are called problems which exclude an answer.
All the dissenters are stupid,
but they consider themselves wise.
They fail to recognise properly the foun kinds of propositions
and make up one distinguishing proposition.
It is like the fool who cuts into parts the coins and other things
and who ruins the coins so they become two pieces.
The fools are also like this.
They take care of their home chores
and they do not feel that this is out of the ordinary.
One day they take care of a certain matter,lg==
the next day they find another occupation.lg==
The various Buddhas come out like giant dragonslg==
the sound of thunder spreads throughout the world,lg==
the rain of the Buddhist truth goes unhindered,lg==
but because of their domestic preoccupations they hear none of thislg==
and they do not understand that death will suddenly arrive.lg==
They miss out on the gathering of the many Buddhaslg==
and they do not obtain the treasures of the Buddhist truth.lg==
Forever they dwell in the Evil Path, and they suffer distress.lg==
They turn their back on so as to discard the correct Buddhist truth.lg==
That man was contemplating the jug which was of vulgar daily concern,lg==
and to the end he did not make up his mind to seek the Buddhist truth.lg==
Therefore he lost the benefit of the Buddhist truthlg==
and forever he never reached a time of liberation.lg==
He turned round, got out of the water and sat down again.
After a short while the water cleared up
and there appeared again the golden colour.
He entered the inside of the pond again
and he raked up the mud and looked for the thing another time,
but again he did not get it.
Now the father was looking for his son.
He found what he was looking for and asked his son:
"What are you doing,
being so exhausted."
The son addressed his father politely and said:
On the bottom of this water there is genuine gold.
Time and again I have thrown myself into the water,
wanting to rake up the mud and get it.
I got tired out all right, but I did not get hold of the gold I was looking for."
The father looked at the reflection of the gold at the bottom of the water
and he understood that this gold was in fact on a tree.
The source of his understanding of this was how the reflection appeared on the bottom of the water.
The father said:
"Certainly this must have been a bird with the gold in its beak which put the gold on the tree."
The son followed his father's suggestion and got up on the tree, and got hold of the gold.
All the stupid peoplelg==
devoid of wisdom as they are are also like this.lg==
While placed in the Aggregate of Absence of Selflg==
they arbitrarily generate imaginings about the Presence of Self.lg==
It is like that man who saw the reflection of the goldlg==
and who laboured hard in order to find it,lg==
but who made an empty effort without getting anything (as long as he was looking for things in the water).lg==
The Brahmadeva King told him and said:
"Do not act out this idea!
You are unable to create these things."
However, the man did not use the words from Heaven
and he wanted to create the things.
When Brahmadeva saw the creatures created by his disciple
he went on to say to him:
"You have made the head too large,
you have made the neck very small,
You have made the hand too large,
and you have made the arms very small.
You made the legs extremely small,
and you made the heels extremely large.
This looks like a Pisheshe devil.
From this one should understand that whatever one creates oneself is not what Brahmā can create.
The various Buddhas in preaching the Buddhist law, will not approach the two Extremes:
they will neither approach the cutting off (of the succesion of lives),
nor will they approach the extreme of permanence (of one life).
It is like those of the Noble Eightfold Path preaching the Buddhist Law:
the dissenters, when theyh see the matters of cutting off and of permanence
will then generate the fixation on these.
They cheat and mislead the people of this world
The laws they make look like the true Buddhist Law,
but what they explain is in fact not that true Buddhist Law.
The doctor at a later stage visited the man and on that occasion asked him:
"Well, has your disease been cured or not?"
The sick person replied and said:
"Doctor, you have ordered me regularly to eat the meat of a pheasant.
So now, having eaten up a pheasant, I dare not henceforth go on to eat this kind of meat."
The doctor replied and said:
"If some time ago the pheasant has already been eaten up, why did you not go on to eat a new one?
Why did you now only eat one pheasant, hoping to get to cure your disease. (Postposed clause!)
All dissenters are also like this.
They hear the Buddha and the boddhisattvas, the supreme excellent doctors of the soul, explain
that they must unravel their own consciousness.
The heretics hold onto current popular prejudice
and they imagine that in the past, the future and the present there is one kind of awareness,
and that there is no periodic change (over time) in this.
It is like eating one pheasant.
That is why they are unable to cure the disease of their stupidity and of their worries.
The supremely wise Buddhas have have taught the dissenters to rid themselves of their set views concerning the constancy of things.
As for all features of the world (dharmas), all thoughts of them will arise and disappear.
How could there one kind of consciousness which is constant and does not change.
It is like the case of the mundane physician who instructs the man to go on eating pheasantso that he gets to have his disease cured.
The Buddha is also like this.
He teaches the living creatures,
and he causes them to understand all features of the world:
They are all periodically destroyed and therefore they are not permanent;
they are follow upon each other and thereful they are not cut off (but remain part of the Wheel).

p.seg: At the time, among the fellow travellers, there was one who woke up from his sleep and suddenly saw there was a devil by the fire.
In fact he did not closely investigate the matter,
left him alone and ran away.
Thus he scared the wits out of these people.
All the friends ran away.
At the time, among the friends, the man wearing the devil's cloak also went along chasing the others as fast as he could,
and he ran off.
When his fellow travellers saw that he was behind
they imagined that he wanted to harm them,
and that redoubled their fear.
They leapt across mountains and rivers,
and threw themselves into waterways,
so their bodies were badly injured,
and they were tired out and extremely worn out.
When it got to the next morning
only then did they understand that he wasn't a ghost.
All the common people are also like this.
They find themselves in worries, and they hunger after and are poor in the good Buddhist truths
but they desire to seek far way constant pleasures, and the purity of the Self as their "supreme nourishment in the form of teaching".
And so within their persons they wildly make plans for an Ego/Self.
Because of their (mistaken) doctrine of the Self, they float along in the world of transmigration.
They are chased by worries, and they do not find peace with themselves.
They are engulfed the Three Wrong Paths, and in their wickedness hasten towards the waterways.
The arrival of the next morning illustrates that the night of transmigration is over,
and only when through wisdom they understand things clearly will they come to understand that there is no such thing as the genuine Self/Ego.
Afterwards there was another person
who considered himself to be courageous even more than the aforementioned man
who again heard from a bystander who said that in this house there constantly were evil spirits
and he immediately wished to go in.
He threw open the gate and was about to lead the way forward.
At that time those who had got in first (with him) imagined that this was a ghost (inside),
and they pushed the gate shut so that they blocked it and refused to obey the order to proceed.
Those who came afterwards also thought there was a ghost.
The two (courageous) men fought it out until dawn.
When they had finished fighting each other, first then he understood that it was not a ghost he had been fighting with.
All the people of this world are also like this.
The carmic causes for a time come together and there is no real master.
But one by one they analyse who is that Self.
And so all the sentient beings wildly assess who is right and who is wrong,
and in a forced way they produce quarrelling litigation.
They are like these two people, and there is no difference bewtween them.
As it happened, just as her husband was on a formal mission to a neighbouring state
the woman secretly put into practice a plan.
she made poisonous medical pills
and was hoping to use these to harm the husband.
Deceitfully the talked to her husband, and said:
You are now about to go on a distant mission
and i am worried that you will be short of things.
Now I have made five hundred Pills of Delight,
and you may use them as provisions
to give to you.
If, when you leave the state you get to an alien terriory,
then, when you are in trouble from hunger, then you can take these and eat them.
The husband acted according to this proposal.
By the time he arrived in the foreign parts
he had not yet got to eating any of the pills.
In the darkness of the nighttime he spent the night in the woods.
He was afraid of wicked wild animals
and he got up onto a tree in order to avoid them.
The pills of delight he forgot and put at the bottom of the tree.
And then that very night he came upon 500 thieves
who stole 500 horses from that king, as well as other property.
They came to rest under the tree,
and because they had run away
they were all hungry and thirsty.
At the bottom of the tree they noticed the pills of delight.
After the thieves had got hold of them all
they each ate one pill.
The power of the poison in the medicine pills was strong
and the 500 thieves all died at the same time.
At that time the man on the tree, when it came to dawn,
saw that this crowd of thieves had died under his tree,
and fraudulently he used daggers and arrows to slaughter and shoot at the dead bodies.
He collected their saddles and horses as well as the goods
and hastened towards the capital.
At that time the king was leading a large crowd of people
to follow the thieves' footprints and pursue them.
Thus it so happened that our man met the king mid-way,
and that king asked as follows:
"Who are you,
and where did you get these horses?"
Our man replied as follows:
"I come from such-and-such a state
and on my way I ran into this bunch of robbers.
We have been cutting and shooting at each other.
The five hundred thieves have now all died under a tree.
Because of this I have obtained these horses and these treasures
and have come to seek refuge in your Majesty's country.
If you do not trust me
you can send someone to go and observe the place where the thieves received their wounds and were killed.
The king then sent his close collaborators to go and investigate the matter,
and in the event it turned out as our man had said.
The king then was delighted
and he sighed that there had never been any such thing.
When the king had returned home
he richly rewarded the man
presented him with treasures
and enfeoffed him in a village.
The seasoned ministers of this king all generated envy and they said to the king:
"This is a man from a distant place
and he cannot quite be trusted.
How come you suddenly give him preferential treatment in this excessively generous way,
so it gets to the stage
where he goes beyond us seasoned ministers?"
When the man from distant lands heard this he made this speech:
"Who has the courage to try his strength with/against me?
Let use compare our abilities in the open field."
The old cronies were astonished and no one had the courage to take him on.
At a later time, in the large open countryside of that state there was a wicked lion
which blocked the way and was killing people,
and which was disrupting the royal thoroughfare.
At that time the seasoned ministers discussed the matter formally together:
"This man from distant parts considers himself as so tough that no one can take him on.
But if he now will be able to kill that lion and remove harm from the state
then that will truly be outstanding!"
When the king heard this
he gave them daggers and clubs so they could immediately go after him.
When the man from distant parts then received his orders,
he stiffened his determination
and directed himself to the lion's haunt.
When the lion saw him
he roared wildly and leapt forward.
The man from distant parts panicked
and immediately climbed up a tree.
The lion opened his maul wide
and turned up his head, upwards towards the tree.
The man was terrified:
he lost grip of the dagger he held
and dropped it into the lion's mouth,
and the lion died on the spot.
At that point the man from distant parts was jumping up and down with joy
and he came to make his polite report to the king about what had happened.
The king received him with redoubled preferential attentions.
At that time the people in that state suddenly came to show their respect foor the foreigner,
and they were all full of praise for him.
The wife's happiness pills illustrate morally unclean positive action.
When the King sends off his emissary, this illustrates good friends.
When the husband gets to another state, this illustrates the various Buddist Heavens.
When he kills the thieves this illustrates the achieving the first stage of enlightenment, the resolute cutting off of the Five Desires and of all the worries.
The meeting the king of that state illustrates the encountering a sage.
When the established people of the state produce jealousy that illustrates the dissenters who, when they see someone who has wisdeom and who can cut off their Worries and their Five Desires,
then go on to produce slander saying: there is nothing to this.

When the man from far-away lands was arrogant and said: "Among the established ministers there is none who can equal me, that illustrates that one does not have the courage to oppose the heterodox people.
The killing of the lion illustrates the destruction of evil demons.
He stops the Worries and subjugates the evil demons.
And then he manages obtain the enfeoffment and rewards in the form of the ultimate truth unconnected with the physical world.
When he constantly gets scared, this illustrates that being weaker one can gain control of what is stronger.
Although at the beginning he has no pure mind
nonetheless through his generosity he encountered a good friend/a Buddhist teacher
and then gained the excellent reward.
Even when one is impurely generous, things still work out like this.
How much more so when with a good heart one gladly practises generosity.
Thus one should, in the place where one cultivates one's blessings, use all one's energy to cultivate generosity.
